intro: Chamaesyce ocellata, commonly known as the spotted sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae, which includes many species with unique floral structures. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and hairy, succulent leaves that help it retain moisture in arid environments. It typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in coastal areas. Its common name refers to the distinctive, eye-like markings on its leaves, which are a key identifying feature.
